results.title: Five Sci-Fi Classics, One Summer: How 1982 Shaped Our Present
results.abstract: “Blade Runner,” “E.T.,” “Tron,” “The Wrath of Khan” and “The Thing” all arrived that one season 40 years ago to become indelible and influential.
results.byline: By Adam Nayman and Sinna Nasseri
des_facet: Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (Movie)

multimedia.caption: The future is now: The photographer Sinna Nasseri captured images of present-day New York City as it might have been predicted by science fiction films of the 1980s. Above, a replica of the DeLorean from “Back to the Future” was on display in Times Square.

The future is now: The photographer Sinna Nasseri captured images of present-day New York City as it might have been predicted by science fiction films of the 1980s. Above, a replica of the DeLorean from “Back to the Future” was on display in Times Square.

results.title: It Came From the ’80s
results.abstract: We asked four young stars of the present to watch the influential sci-fi films that seemed futuristic back in the day. Here’s what they thought.

results.title: Pregnant Men Were a Movie Punchline. Now They’re Horror Villains.
results.abstract: The idea of the pregnant man has long been mined for Hollywood comedy. This summer, he becomes a menace.

multimedia.caption: Pop culture has long been obsessed with the prospect of male pregnancy, though it has mostly been pitched as a comedic gambit, like in “Junior,” starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, left, and Danny DeVito.

Pop culture has long been obsessed with the prospect of male pregnancy, though it has mostly been pitched as a comedic gambit, like in “Junior,” starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, left, and Danny DeVito.

Pop culture has long been obsessed with the prospect of male pregnancy, though it has mostly been pitched as a comedic gambit, like in “Junior,” starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, left, and Danny DeVito.

results.title: ‘Bullet Train’ Review: Ride and Die
results.abstract: Brad Pitt plays an amiable assassin who gets stuck on a Japanese high-speed train with a motley crew of other killers and no easy way out.

results.title: How the Indian Action Spectacular ‘RRR’ Became a Smash in America
results.abstract: The unusual decision to rerelease the film a few weeks after its initial run has drawn enthusiastic audiences even though it’s available on Netflix.

multimedia.caption: Set in Delhi during the early 1920s, “RRR” follows two patriotic but philosophically opposed men (Ram Charan, left, and N.T. Rama Rao Jr.) who team up to rescue a kidnapped girl from British colonial officials.

Set in Delhi during the early 1920s, “RRR” follows two patriotic but philosophically opposed men (Ram Charan, left, and N.T. Rama Rao Jr.) who team up to rescue a kidnapped girl from British colonial officials.

results.title: At the BlackStar Film Festival, a Revelatory Understanding of Cinema
results.abstract: Specializing in work by Black, brown and Indigenous directors, the annual Philadelphia event showcases experimental work from around the world.

multimedia.caption: “One Take Grace” is the result of a collaboration between the director Lindiwe Matshikiza and a South African domestic worker, Mothiba Grace Bapela.

results.title: She’s the Secret Weapon in a Film About the Thai Cave Rescue
results.abstract: For Ron Howard’s retelling of the 2018 ordeal, Pattrakorn Tungsupakul not only played the mother of a stranded boy, she also made key script contributions.

multimedia.caption: Pattrakorn Tungsupakul said working on “Thirteen Lives” was both refreshing and strange after her experience in the less collaborative Thai television industry.

results.title: ‘Memory Box’ Review: Reanimating a Painful Past

results.title: Pixar’s Ousted Founder Returns With Apple and ‘Luck’
results.abstract: John Lasseter was toppled five years ago by allegations about his workplace behavior. He’s back with an animated film and a studio that could be Pixar 2.0.

multimedia.caption: John Lasseter's successes at Pixar included the “Toy Story” and “Cars” franchises.
John Lasseter's successes at Pixar included the “Toy Story” and “Cars” franchises.

results.title: Nichelle Nichols, Lieutenant Uhura on ‘Star Trek,’ Dies at 89
results.abstract: She was among the first Black women to have a leading role in a TV series. She later worked with NASA to recruit minorities for the space program.

multimedia.caption: Nichelle Nichols on “Star Trek” in 1967. She played Lieutenant Uhura, an officer and a highly educated technician who maintained a businesslike demeanor in performing her duties.
Nichelle Nichols on “Star Trek” in 1967. She played Lieutenant Uhura, an officer and a highly educated technician who maintained a businesslike demeanor in performing her duties.

results.title: Mary Alice, Tony Winner for Her Role in ‘Fences,’ Dies at 85
results.abstract: A former Chicago schoolteacher, she appeared on TV in ‘A Different World’ and ‘I’ll Fly Away,’ winning an Emmy in 1993.

multimedia.caption: The actress Mary Alice in 1987, when she was playing Rose Maxson in the play “Fences.” She won a Tony Award for best featured actress in a play.
The actress Mary Alice in 1987, when she was playing Rose Maxson in the play “Fences.” She won a Tony Award for best featured actress in a play.
